Award.AwardTitle: NCS-FO: Integrated neurocognitive process models of individual differences in children’s math problem solving strategies, learning and development
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project, led by a team of researchers at Stanford University, is to develop novel neurocognitive models that integrate behavioral and neural (fMRI, functional magnetic resonance imaging) data to understand the computational, cognitive, and brain mechanisms underlying individual differences in mathematical problem solving and strategy use, the effects of training, and longitudinal development. Understanding how symbols are processed in the brain has direct implications for education and the remediation of cognitive difficulties. The researchers will perform sophisticated computational analyses on a dataset derived from children 7 to 12 years of age in an fMRI study, a tutoring study, and a longitudinal study. The findings of this study will provide a basis for customized training and will provide novel platforms for diagnostic and intervention procedures for learning difficulties. This project is funded by Integrative Strategies for Understanding Neural and Cognitive Systems (NCS), a multidisciplinary program jointly supported by the Directorates for Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR), Engineering (ENG), and Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences (SBE).

This research will leverage extensive behavioral data, cognitive assessments, as well as brain imaging data, to model moment-by-moment changes in latent cognitive dynamics associated with mathematical problem solving. The multidisciplinary approach described here seeks to develop unsupervised computational models to infer differences in the latent cognitive strategies used by an individual on a trial-by-trial basis. Specifically, this project aims to (1) develop computational cognitive models for inferring latent problem-solving dynamics and strategy use, (2) develop novel integrated neurocognitive models to identify distinct and overlapping brain circuits underlying latent problem-solving dynamics and strategy use, and (3) determine integrated cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying the impact of cognitive tutoring on changes in latent problem-solving dynamics and strategy use. The planned studies will help in dissociating mathematical problem solving into multiple cognitive sub-processes, characterizing sources of individual differences across these sub-processes, identifying how each of these might relate to difficulties in problem solving, and evaluate whether these cognitive sub-processes may be remediated by cognitive tutoring programs. Ultimately, this research will enhance our understanding of dynamic cognitive processes and problem-solving strategies in children’s numerical cognition and provide new insights into latent behavioral dynamics associated with typical and atypical math abilities in children.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our findings will inform academic and education policy, provide a basis for customized training and intervention at large scales including educator driven and online platforms, and provide novel platforms for prodromal diagnosis of learning difficulties and dyscalculia. Beyond advancement of scientific knowledge, our proposed work will through research and education activities contribute to broader achievement of societally relevant outcomes in the context of cognitive development and educational neuroscience, a multidisciplinary field with few formal training programs. We have published multiple research articles in high-profile journals, and presented our work at scientific conferences. The specific outcomes of this project can be categorized into two broad areas – findings advancing our fundamental understanding of mathematical cognition and learning, and the development of innovative methodological approaches that are applicable to wider range of neuroscientific domains.

 1. Advances in the foundational understanding of latent neurocognitive processes underlying mathematical cognition:

First, our project uncovered multiple latent novel measures underlying individual differences in mathematical cognition, including measures like performance monitoring, metacognitive abilities, strategy preferences, relative efficiencies of different strategies, and evolution of uncertainty in strategy selection, without the need to rely on any form of self-reporting, which may sometimes be susceptible to biases. Many of these measures have not been inferred in prior work. Our cognitive models identified novel relationships of both math anxiety and relative attitude to mathematics with the selection and efficiency of problem-solving strategies, showing how math anxiety and relative attitude to mathematics can influence errors and reaction times through separate processes

Second, we elucidated functional brain circuits for some of these distinct cognitive subprocesses involved in mathematical cognition, that go beyond traditional associations between a particular cognitive task, and show how a specific neural region or circuit is implicated in a particular nuanced aspect of the task, such as performance monitoring. By mapping individual differences for which elemental neurocognitive processes and brain circuits might be implicated in learning differences, we get a step closer towards identifying personalized neurocognitive targets for intervention.

Third, using a biologically inspired deep neural network of math problem solving, we identified specific neural mechanisms that can potentially cause impaired learning in children. We showed how additional training in a digital twin (AI representation of human learners) could remedy mathematical difficulties associated with these neural mechanisms causing slower learning, such as higher neural excitability.

Fourth, we improved our understanding of the neurocognitive impact of cognitive tutoring. We found how specific cognitive training can impact the efficiency of retrieval based strategies, but not the preference or metacognitive selection of different strategies, and how such training is related to hippocampal connectivity and modularity of brain regions involved in numerical problem solving. We found empirical evidence that integrated number sense tutoring remediates aberrant neural representations in children with mathematical disabilities, and showed how short‐term number sense training can recapitulate long‐term neurodevelopmental changes from childhood to adolescence. Together, these advances get us a step closer towards personalized tutoring and training algorithms.

Fifth, we have improved our understanding of longitudinal developmental trajectories of mathematical cognition, by incorporating single-trial GLM based neural (fMRI) measures and dynamic latent cognitive parameters.

 2. Innovative methodological advances: Our project has developed multiple novel computational modeling approaches that fundamentally advance the tools, methods, and analytical frameworks available to cognitive neuroscientists working not just in mathematical cognition, but also in a variety of cognitive and decision-making domains:

First, we have developed innovative cognitive models that allow us to dissociate behavior into elemental neurocognitive subprocesses (e.g. switching between cognitive states, metacognitive selection of different strategies, effect of sequential problem-solving and decision making, impact of performance monitoring, etc.) which capture rapidly changing dynamics of behavior and cognition. This allowed us to map how changes in neural (fMRI) recordings over time within an individual are related to the evolution of different neurocognitive subprocesses. We demonstrated that these inferences characterize non-ergodicity in brain-behavior associations, and that capturing within-individual dynamic measures reveals novel brain-behavior associations that cannot always be obtained using traditional methods. This opens up new avenues for neuroscientists to explore in multiple domains.

Second, we developed digital twins – biologically plausible personalized Deep Neural Networks, and showed the feasibility of using this approach to understand individual differences in how children learn. We demonstrated how these digital twin could be used to investigate the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying learning disabilities. This approach provides another avenue for neuroscientists not only to examine and test theories underlying individual differences in learning across different domains, but also opens avenues for targeted, personalized training and intervention strategies designed to bridge cognitive gaps in affected children.

Together, our novel computational approach and methods are widely applicable to the study of problem solving, memory, and decision-making and offer powerful new methods for cognitive and developmental neuroscience, and the interpretation of brain-behavior associations, more broadly, in multiple cognitive domains.
